subject: Re: [junit] RE: Is there a tool which generates JUnit-test stubs?

Subject: Re: [junit] RE: Is there a tool which generates JUnit-test stubs?

Starting a new project of maintaining one are two different problems.
The XP 'test-first' method is well suited for a new project, but can be
dangerous is applied blindly to an already developped project.

   > On a larger project, I agree that the initial benefit is reduced, but
   > there is a tangible benefit of having the initial unit test
   > *structure* in place.

     I don't think that the time needed to generate stubs for a small or
large project make the difference (if it's only an empty TestCase per
class + AllTests.java, maybe a couple of seconds).  The good think is
that you're showing the way to go.  The developers will have someting to
work on immediately.

   > 2. As for JTest, it will do even something else for you, which is to
   > come up (through reflection
   > and some other techniques) with a basic set of unit tests that can be
   > manually augmented later


I always have problem with tools that generate "tests" for your code.
But as I don't know JTest, take my comment as general.

Writing tests is verifying what the class _must_ do and not what the
class _is_ doing.  Because the tool has normally no way of guessing what
the class must do, it tests its actual behaviour.  To my opinion, these
"tests" do not help you to find bugs (in general), but can be seen as a
"safety net" (because once generated, they should all pass).  If one of
these tests failes after adding a feature, it tells you that you changed
the behaviour of your application.  It's up to you then to review the
"test" and see if it's still accurate.  But maybe JTest acts differently.

-Vladimir
